channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Star Maestro, Fighting Brain Cancer, Finds Peace in Music
item.description: Michael Tilson Thomas, who returned to Tanglewood, where his career first took off, refuses to be confined by his illness.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Tilson Thomas rehearsing with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood on Saturday.

item.title: Katie Gregson-MacLeod Sang About a ‘Complex’ Love. TikTok Responded.
item.description: The 21-year-old Scottish folk singer-songwriter found a sudden hit by tapping into the platform’s appetite for melancholy with a striking, sorrowful chorus.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregson-MacLeod began posting to TikTok in 2020, a few months into the pandemic, and had been studying at college and working in a coffee shop when her song took off.

item.title: With ‘Tár,’ Todd Field Returns to Directing. Where Has He Been?
item.description: Sixteen years after “In the Bedroom” and “Little Children” made waves, he’s nervous about stepping back into the limelight with a hot-button story.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Tim Barber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Field said he got so used to working on unfilmed projects that “the idea that I was going to have to go away from home for over a year and actually make a film just seemed so absurd to me.”

item.title: A Leading Choreographer Joins the War Effort, With Classical Ballet
item.description: Alexei Ratmansky, one of the most important figures in ballet, is supporting Ukraine by staging “Giselle” with a company made up of Ukrainian refugees.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexei Ratmansky at a rehearsal of “Giselle,” which is being danced by a newly formed company of Ukrainian dancers who have fled the war.

item.title: How Did ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Get Those Dogfight Scenes? Joseph Kosinski Explains.
item.description: The director behind the biggest movie of 2022 so far discusses trying to make a movie that can’t be traced to any particular year and the meaning of Dad Cinema.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bloom

item.title: Laura Linney to Return to Broadway in New David Auburn Play
item.description: “Summer, 1976,” about a friendship between two women in Ohio, will open next spring at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Laura Linney will play “a fiercely iconoclastic artist and single mom” in David Auburn's new play.

item.title: Venice Film Festival 2022: What to Watch For
item.description: The event fires the award-season starting pistol with some of the most anticipated films of the year — including “White Noise,” “The Whale” and “Don’t Worry Darling.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Frieze Debuts in Seoul, With Big-Name Galleries and a Hometown Spectacle
item.description: The art fair takes on a whole new continent this fall, showcasing more than 110 galleries in the South Korean capital.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos

item.title: Gabriel Byrne’s ‘Walking With Ghosts’ Is Heading to Broadway
item.description: The play, adapted from his memoir of the same name, will run for 75 performances starting in October.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:description: Gabriel Byrne, whose play “Walking With Ghosts” is coming to Broadway.

item.title: An Orchestra Brings Harmony to a Region of Discord
item.description: The Pan-Caucasian Youth Orchestra unites players from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Russia, Turkey and Ukraine with a message of peace and dialogue.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher

item.title: After a Long, Starring Run, Will Racism at Last Get the Hook?
item.description: We can no longer ignore the theater’s systemic inequities. But leaving them behind may remake the industry in unexpected ways.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.category: We See You, White American Theater (Theater Coalition)

item.title: ‘Monarch’ Heralds a New Family Empire, This One With a Texas Twang
item.description: Starring Trace Adkins, Anna Friel and Susan Sarandon, the new Fox musical series brings “Empire”-style dynastic drama to the world of country music.
item.dc:creator: Chris Vognar

item.title: John Adams, an American Master at 75
item.description: Adams, arguably our greatest living composer, has done operas inspired by recent history. In “Antony and Cleopatra,” he turns to Shakespeare.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Adams’s 75th year is being celebrated not only with the premiere of a new opera, but also with a 40-disc retrospective box set on the Nonesuch label.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Mexico City
item.description: Juan Villoro, who spent over two decades perfecting one book about Mexico City, recommends reading on the city he loves. “Mexico is too complex,” a visitor said. “It needs to be read.”
item.dc:creator: Juan Villoro
item.category: Horizontal Vertigo: A City Called Mexico (Book)
On the Plain of Snakes: A Mexican Journey (Book)

item.title: Review: Finding Community in ‘As You Like It’
item.description: This shimmering Shakespeare adaptation at the Delacorte Theater retains the outline of the original, while making space for songs. You don’t have to sing along, though you may want to.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:description: Adapted by Laurie Woolery, who directs, and the singer-songwriter Shaina Taub, who provides the music and lyrics, “As You Like It” unites its dozens of actors and its hundreds of audience members.

item.title: Ruby C. Williams, Folk Artist With a Produce Stand, Dies at 94
item.description: Her colorful paintings started out as advertisements for her farm stand in Florida. Before long, her works found their way to art galleries.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The folk artist Ruby C. Williams around 2009 in front of her produce stand in a rural part of Florida, east of Tampa.

item.title: Daniel Barenboim, Star Conductor, Withdraws from ‘Ring’ Cycle in Berlin
item.description: “I must now give priority to my health and concentrate on my complete recovery,” the conductor said.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Daniel Barenboim at a concert in Berlin supporting the people of Ukraine, in March.

item.title: A Utica Sculpture Studio Is Ransacked, and 5 Children Are Arrested
item.description: Sculpture Space, a residency program, was vandalized over the weekend. The police said Tuesday they had charged five juveniles between the ages of 8 and 11 in connection with the crime.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Officials at Sculpture Space, a residency program for artists, shared this photograph showing the damage to its studio in Utica, N.Y., after it was vandalized.

item.title: Book Review: “Partisans,” by Nicole Hemmer
item.description: A new book by the historian Nicole Hemmer charts the demise of Reagan-style optimism and the birth of a rage-and-fear-based politics on the right.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Partisans: The Conservative Revolutionaries Who Remade American Politics in the 1990s (Book)

item.title: Lee Bul Is an Artist in Pursuit of Balance
item.description: Lee Bul, a contemporary Korean artist, blends old traditions and new techniques. Work from her latest series, “Perdu,” will be shown at Frieze Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri

item.title: Exploring Spain’s Arab Influence
item.description: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Córdoba’s Mosque-Cathedral, or La Mezquita, was one of the first and grandest mosques in Europe.

item.title: Maggie O’Farrell Looks for Stories Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Her latest book, “The Marriage Portrait,” imagines the life of the girl who is thought to have inspired Robert Browning’s famous poem “My Last Duchess.”
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Robert Ormerod for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author at home with her daughters. Overlooked narratives, she said, “are the ones that interest me.”

item.title: In Seoul, Perrotin Adds a Second Gallery
item.description: The global dealer opened a second space in South Korea’s capital just before the Frieze and Kiaf fairs, with an eye toward new artists and new buyers.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher

item.title: For the Artist Do Ho Suh, Memories Are a Medium
item.description: Work by Do Ho Suh, being shown in Seoul and New York in September, highlights the global nature of the art world — and of his own personal journey.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.media:credit: Nolwen Cifuentes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Suh wanted to study marine biology before he was bitten by the art bug. While studying Korean painting at Seoul National University, he explains, “I started to perceive time and space in a different way.”

item.title: San Francisco’s Art Market Struggles in the Shadow of Los Angeles
item.description: Though some small galleries are opening or expanding, the mega dealers have closed shop, a blow to an area with a vibrant artistic history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Institute of Contemporary Art San Francisco
item.media:credit: Ulysses Ortega for The New York Times

item.title: An Orlando Museum’s Disputed Basquiats Are Gone. Its Leadership Is, Too.
item.description: In the wake of an F.B.I. raid, the crisis at the Orlando Museum of Art deepened amid upheaval on its board and the resignation of its interim director.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Orlando Museum of Art is facing a crisis, with five board members ousted and an interim director who resigned suddenly.

item.title: ‘The Patient’ Review: The Doctor Is In. In the Basement.
item.description: The team behind “The Americans” returns with a darkly comic tale starring Steve Carell as a psychotherapist in chains.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: In “The Patient,” Steve Carell plays a therapist who is kidnapped by one of his patients, a serial killer who wants to be cured of his murderous impulses.

item.title: Jordan Peele Says There May Be More ‘Nope’ Stories to Come
item.description: We asked the writer-director about that standing shoe, a character called Nobody and fan theories about his flying-saucer movie. This is what he told us.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Album Ties ‘Encanto’ for Most Weeks at No. 1 This Year
item.description: “Un Verano Sin Ti,” a streaming blockbuster, notches its ninth time at the top of Billboard’s chart. Rod Wave’s “Beautiful Mind,” last week’s No. 1, drops to second place.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Bad Bunny, performing at Yankee Stadium for the MTV Video Music Awards broadcast on Sunday.

item.title: ‘House of the Dragon’: Steve Toussaint on Playing Lord Corlys
item.description: One of the most powerful people in Westeros made his reputation as a fearless sailor. The actor who plays him does better on land.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: As the powerful Lord Corlys, Steve Toussaint plays one of the few people in the Seven Kingdoms who doesn’t have to mince his words with the king.

item.title: Taylor Swift Announces a New Album, ‘Midnights’
item.description: The LP, described by Swift as “the story of 13 sleepless nights,” is due Oct. 21. It will be her 10th studio album, and her fifth release in just over two years.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Taylor Swift announced the release date for a new album, “Midnights,” onstage at the MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night.

item.title: Wolfgang Tillmans: Older, Wiser, Cooler
item.description: In a 35-year career celebrated at MoMA this fall, the artist has concerned himself with “the poetry of looking,” blurring the line between party and protest. But, increasingly, it’s politics on his mind.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Anderson
item.media:credit: Daniel Arnold for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Civil rights have to be defended, and democracy has to be defended. I was always aware of that,” Wolfgang Tillmans said. “In recent years, it’s become a superstrong awareness.” Above, the artist installing his show at MoMA.

item.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Race for the Championship’ and ‘Stargirl’
item.description: USA Network airs its NASCAR documentary series. And the third season of the CW show based on the DC Comics character premieres.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Joey Logano in “Race for the Championship.”

item.title: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap
item.description: Rhaenyra receives some surprising news, and Viserys likely sets into motion the thing he’s been trying to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner
item.media:description: Things got extra complicated between Rhaenyra (Milly Alcock) and her dad this week.

item.title: Leaving Los Angeles
item.description: Hollywood wasn’t exactly the Hollywood you see in movies.
item.dc:creator: Annie Hamilton

item.title: A Festival That Conjures the Magic of H.P. Lovecraft and Beyond
item.description: At the Rhode Island event, revelers danced to murder ballads and celebrated all things weird. They even found time to reckon with the writer’s racism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The weird is a way to connect with the world around us and make sense of it,” said one panelist at NecronomiCon Providence in Rhode Island.

item.title: Jaimie Branch, Trumpeter Who Crossed Genre Lines, Dies at 39
item.description: One of the most dynamic trumpet players in contemporary music, she forged a direct emotional, and even spiritual, connection with her listeners.
item.dc:creator: Mike Rubin
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trumpeter Jaimie Branch in performance at Le Poisson Rouge in New York City in 2016, with Jason Ajemian on bass.

item.title: Counting the Population Has Always Been Political
item.description: In the deft and surprisingly lively “Democracy’s Data,” Dan Bouk explores the uses, misuses and failures of the U.S. Census.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.category: Democracy's Data: The Hidden Stories in the US Census and How to Read Them (Book)

item.title: Ashes of Nichelle Nichols, Lieutenant Uhura From “Star Trek,” to Be Launched Into Deep Space
item.description: The ashes of Ms. Nichols, who played Lieutenant Uhura on “Star Trek,” will be on a Vulcan rocket to be launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., later this year.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The United Launch Alliance Vulcan rocket will carry a portion of Ms. Nichols’s ashes, as well as cremated remains, DNA samples and messages of greetings.

item.title: Beefcake, Goethe’s Boswell and the Greeks
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Joey DeFrancesco, Reigning King of the Jazz Organ, Dies at 51
item.description: A prodigy whose playing had drawn raves since he was a teenager, he helped bring the Hammond B3 back into the jazz lineup.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:credit: Willie Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The organist Joey DeFrancesco performing with the saxophonist Dave Sanborn at the Blue Note in New York in 2010. (The drummer, not pictured, was Byron Landham.) Although Mr. Sanborn was the leader, one critic wrote, “It’s often as much Mr. DeFrancesco’s show, and sometimes more so.”

item.title: Virginia Patton Moss, ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’ Actress, Dies at 97
item.description: The last surviving adult member of the film’s cast, she played the sister-in-law to James Stewart’s George Bailey. Three years later, she quit Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Virginia Patton as Ruth Dakin in “It’s a Wonderful Life” (1946) with, from left, Todd Karns as her husband, Harry; James Stewart as George Bailey, Harry's brother; and Thomas Mitchell as the brothers’ Uncle Billy.

item.title: Catching Up With ‘Star Trek,’ the Quiet Franchise
item.description: Marvel and “Star Wars” make more noise, but “Trek” cruises along with five current series. (Pro tip: Don’t sleep on the animated shows.)
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.category: Star Trek: Strange New Worlds (TV Program)

item.title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
item.description: The brilliance of Chantal Akerman, Martin Scorsese and Ryuichi Sakamoto is on display in this month’s recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Sy Johnson, Arranger Who Worked Closely With Mingus, Dies at 92
item.description: A jazz Renaissance man, he arranged many of the bassist’s later works and also wrote reviews, took photographs and composed his own music.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Joe E. Tata, Peach Pit Owner in ‘Beverly Hills, 90210,’ Dies at 85
item.description: As Nat Bussichio, Mr. Tata doled out fatherly advice to the students who frequented his diner on the hit series, which ran for 10 seasons on Fox.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Joe E. Tata in 2008. Mr. Tata played Nat Bussichio, the friendly owner of the fictional Peach Pit diner, in 238 episodes of “Beverly Hills, 90210.”

item.title: Only Connect: Finding a Way Into Kinetic Light’s ‘Wired’
item.description: Audio descriptions are one path into this disability arts ensemble’s show. In some ways, these mirror the critic’s job: putting dance into words.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laurel Lawson, left, and Alice Sheppard in Kinetic Light’s “Wired” at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘The Invitation’ Review: Nathalie Emmanuel Brings Down the Haunted House
item.description: Nathalie Emmanuel stars as the unwitting belle of an English manor in this middling gothic horror movie that leaves her blind to the blood-red flags waving at every turn.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Decades Later, a Composer Revisits the Piano Concerto
item.description: William Bolcom’s recent work, written for the pianist Igor Levit, is streaming after its premiere earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:description: The composer William Bolcom, whose Piano Concerto No. 2 is now on YouTube, at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich.

item.title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Chooses Dance Veteran as Leader
item.description: Sonja Kostich, a cultural administrator and dancer, will lead the group as it works to expand its audience amid the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Sonja Kostich is expected to start in October. “It should be an art center for everyone,” she said.

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a Ukrainian documentary, a Mexican thriller and a French-Arab drama about poetry and young love.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish
item.category: The Earth Is Blue as an Orange (Movie)
A Tale of Love and Desire (Movie)

item.title: The Secrets Lurking Inside Matisse’s ‘Red Studio’
item.description: Revisiting the landmark exhibition at MoMA, our critic finds clues to a new story line.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: Britney Spears and Elton John’s Mash-up, and 8 More New Songs
item.description: Hear tracks by Margo Price, Julia Jacklin and Michael Kiwanuka.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Are You Strapped In for ‘The Patient’? Steve Carell Was.
item.description: In a new series from the showrunners of “The Americans,” Steve Carell plays a shrink confined to the basement of a killer. They have a lot to talk about.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: The Finnish National Ballet at 100
item.description: What does style mean for this (or any other) company in an increasingly global ballet world?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Kendall

item.title: California Bill Could Restrict the Use of Rap Lyrics in Court
item.description: The bill, which applies more broadly to other forms of creative expression, has unanimously passed the Senate and Assembly and could become law by the end of September.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: The rapper Young Thug has been indicted on federal racketeering charges and prosecutors have used his lyrics as evidence in the case.

item.title: Foreign Films, English Titles and the Dilemma Distributors Face
item.description: Leave as is? Translate? Change altogether? A movie’s success doesn’t depend entirely on what we call it, but it can have a big effect.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold

item.title: Review: “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” by Wendy Wan-Long Shang
item.description: In “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” a Chinese American boy and his family feel as if they’re refighting the U.S. Civil War.
item.dc:creator: Shing Yin Khor
